conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves from above to the right side of the objects.
A cake or dessert with red topping (shadow A), a small cup/container (shadow B), a rolled object, possibly a rolled-up mat or towel (shadow C), a soccer ball (shadow D).
The current shadows appear directly beneath or slightly offset from their objects, indicating the light source is currently positioned somewhat above the scene.
All shadows will shift to the left of their respective objects when the light source moves to the right side.
The distance between objects and shadows will increase when the light source moves to the right side.
Shadows will stretch further to the left when the light source moves to the right side.
Shadow A (cake) will elongate horizontally, becoming longer toward the left. Its width will remain similar.
Shadow B (cup) will elongate significantly to the left and become narrower.
Shadow C (rolled object) will elongate horizontally toward the left while maintaining approximately the same width.
Shadow D (soccer ball) will become an elongated oval shape stretching to the left.
The edges of all shadows will become less distinct (more blurry) as they stretch farther from their objects.
Shadow details will become less defined as the angle of light changes.
If the light is positioned at a low enough angle, some shadows may overlap with each other.
The shadows might merge together if objects are closely positioned.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will shift to the left of their respective objects when the light source moves to the right side.
All shadows will elongate horizontally (become longer) toward the left when the light source moves to the right side.
Shadow shapes will distort from their current forms into more elongated shapes when the light source moves to the right side.
Shadow B (cup) and D (soccer ball) will show the most dramatic elongation due to their height when the light source moves to the right side.
The shadows will become less distinct at their edges as they stretch further from their objects when the light source moves to the right side.
This is due to the change in angle of incident light, which affects how objects block light and cast shadows on the surface.
